title: How to Call a Taxi in London

steps.title: Hail a taxi in crowded or touristy spots.
steps.content: Hail a taxi in crowded or touristy spots. There are over 20,000 licensed “black cabs” in London, so finding one shouldn’t be too tricky. [2] X Research source Tourist destinations and busy spots like Piccadilly Circus should be good places to look for a cab. There are also many taxi stands around the city, particularly near airports, train stations, and hotels. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Look for cabs with a light on top that says "TAXI."
steps.content: Look for cabs with a light on top that says "TAXI." A cab with a switched off light is not available.

steps.title: Stick out your arm as the taxi drives by.
steps.content: Stick out your arm as the taxi drives by. Make sure you are standing in a visible place on the street, but not putting yourself in danger of getting hit by a car, or otherwise holding up traffic.

steps.title: Give your driver an address or the name of the venue you're headed to.
steps.content: Give your driver an address or the name of the venue you're headed to. Either speak to the driver at their window before entering the cab, or as soon as you get in. While you can tell them a particular address, remember that London taxi drivers are very well-versed in their city, and you can usually just tell them the name of the hotel, theater, restaurant, or landmark you’re headed to.

steps.title: Pay according to the meter and don't worry too much about tip.
steps.content: Pay according to the meter and don't worry too much about tip. Fares are determined by meters, beginning at £2.60, and hiking up by 20 pence every 124 meters. Prices rise in the evening and night. [4] X Research source It is not custom to tip your taxi driver more than 10%. Most locals simply round the fare up to the nearest pound. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Look online for taxi companies.
steps.content: Look online for taxi companies. London’s governmental transportation department keeps a list of taxi companies to whom they have licensed the "black cab." The list includes telephone numbers, websites, and emails. Not all companies serve all areas of London, so choose according to your area. You can find it here: https://tfl.gov.uk/modes/taxis-and-minicabs/book-a-taxi

steps.title: Ask your driver if they can be re-booked if you hailed a taxi.
steps.content: Ask your driver if they can be re-booked if you hailed a taxi. If you are getting along with a driver of a cab you hailed, ask them if you can book their cab in advance for your next ride.

steps.title: Accept an extra booking charge of up to £2.
steps.content: Accept an extra booking charge of up to £2. Keep in mind that, depending on the taxi company, there may be extra charges when booking over the phone or through a website. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Book a minicab online or on the phone.
steps.content: Book a minicab online or on the phone. In London, “minicabs” are taxis that can only be booked online, by phone, or through ride apps like Uber; it is illegal to hail a minicab. Minicabs are much cheaper than black cabs, and many companies that offer black cab bookings will also offer minicabs. Minicab fares are not determined by meters, so make sure to ask what the fare is for your destination before booking a minicab. Like black cab drivers, minicab drivers do not expect large tips.

steps.title: Use an Oyster Card for public transportation.
steps.content: Use an Oyster Card for public transportation. Public transportation in London requires an Oyster card, which lets you ride the underground train system, known as “the tube,” and London’s iconic red double decker busses. Buying a Visitor Oyster Card in advance of your travels, or once you get to London, can save you 50% on public transit. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Explore London by foot for a fully immersive experience.
steps.content: Explore London by foot for a fully immersive experience. The cheapest way to get around London is by walking through it, and walking is a good way to fully explore a new city! There are over 1,700 signs around London just to help navigate pedestrians. [8] X Research source You can pick up free pamphlets on walking tour suggestions at tourism centers, or find some online. [9] X Research source
